[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkCommand::execute()] [Error handling] Does the match statement properly propagate all error types from subcommands, or could certain error conditions be silently swallowed leading to misleading success status? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkCommand::execute()] [Async race conditions] Can concurrent execution of multiple NetworkCommand instances cause race conditions in shared state or client connections, potentially leading to incorrect network status reporting? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkCommand::execute()] [Resource exhaustion] Does the async execution properly handle timeouts and cancellation, or can long-running network requests exhaust system resources when multiple commands are executed concurrently? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: format_output() via execute()] [Information disclosure] Does format_output serialize sensitive data from error responses that could leak internal server details, network topology, or validator information to unauthorized users? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: format_output() via execute()] [JSON injection] Can malicious server responses inject crafted JSON that breaks the serde_json::to_string_pretty() serialization, potentially causing command execution or data corruption? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: format_output() via execute()] [Denial of service] Can extremely large NetworkStatusResponse or NetworkOptionsResponse objects cause format_output to consume excessive memory during JSON serialization, leading to OOM crashes? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkListCommand::execute()] [SSRF attack] Does the url_args.client() construction validate the rosetta_api_url parameter, or can an attacker provide arbitrary internal URLs to probe internal services via network_list() calls? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkListCommand::execute()] [TLS validation bypass] When url_args creates the RosettaClient, does it properly validate TLS certificates for HTTPS connections, or can MITM attackers intercept network_list() responses to manipulate network identifiers? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkListCommand::execute()] [Response validation] Does network_list() validate that the returned NetworkListResponse contains valid network identifiers, or can a malicious server return crafted identifiers that cause downstream parsing errors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkListCommand::execute()] [Error propagation] Are network connection errors, timeout errors, and HTTP error responses properly distinguished in the Result type, or could critical network failures be misinterpreted as successful empty responses? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkListCommand::execute()] [Network confusion] Can an attacker-controlled Rosetta server return network identifiers for multiple chains in the NetworkListResponse, causing the CLI to operate on the wrong blockchain network without user awareness? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkOptionsCommand::execute()] [Chain ID validation] Does network_args.network_request() validate the chain_id parameter before sending it to the server, or can invalid chain IDs cause server-side crashes or unexpected behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkOptionsCommand::execute()] [SSRF attack] Does network_options() prevent URL injection through the network_identifier in the NetworkRequest, potentially allowing requests to arbitrary internal endpoints via crafted chain_id values? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkOptionsCommand::execute()] [Operation type manipulation] Can a malicious server return crafted operation types in NetworkOptionsResponse.allow.operation_types that cause parser errors or enable unauthorized transaction construction in other CLI commands? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkOptionsCommand::execute()] [Version confusion] Does the CLI validate the version information (rosetta_version, node_version, middleware_version) returned in NetworkOptionsResponse, or can version mismatches lead to protocol incompatibilities and transaction failures? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkOptionsCommand::execute()] [Error code injection] Can malicious error codes in NetworkOptionsResponse.allow.errors be injected to cause downstream command misinterpretation, potentially masking real errors or triggering incorrect retry logic? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkOptionsCommand::execute()] [Feature flag manipulation] Can timestamp_start_index, historical_balance_lookup, or mempool_coins flags in NetworkOptionsResponse.allow be manipulated to enable API capabilities that should be disabled for security reasons? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkOptionsCommand::execute()] [Response tampering] Does network_options() verify response integrity (e.g., via signatures or checksums), or can MITM attackers modify the NetworkOptionsResponse to change supported operations and error codes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkStatusCommand::execute()] [Chain ID mismatch] Does network_status() verify that the response corresponds to the requested chain_id in network_args, or can a malicious server return status for a different blockchain without detection? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkStatusCommand::execute()] [Block height manipulation] Can the current_block_identifier in NetworkStatusResponse be manipulated to show a fake blockchain state, potentially causing the CLI to accept invalid transactions or report incorrect balances? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkStatusCommand::execute()] [Timestamp manipulation] Does network_status() validate that current_block_timestamp is monotonically increasing and reasonable, or can attackers manipulate timestamps to bypass time-based transaction validations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkStatusCommand::execute()] [Genesis block confusion] Can the genesis_block_identifier be manipulated to point to a different genesis block, causing the CLI to operate on a completely different chain fork without user awareness? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkStatusCommand::execute()] [Sync status exploitation] Can sync_status field be manipulated to falsely indicate the node is synced when it's not, potentially causing the CLI to submit transactions that will fail or be processed on stale state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkStatusCommand::execute()] [Peer information leakage] Does the peers field in NetworkStatusResponse leak sensitive network topology information that could be used to target specific validator nodes for attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta-cli/src/network.rs] [Function: NetworkStatusCommand::execute()] [Integer overflow] Can extremely large block_height values in current_block_identifier cause integer overflow when used in subsequent calculations or comparisons in other CLI commands? (Medium)
